title: 09_aug_lagrangian
text:
Local Duality





Nonlinear Programming Problem


minimizef(𝐱),f,𝐡∈C2,subject to𝐡(𝐱)=𝟎,𝐱∈ℝn,𝐡(𝐱)∈ℝm.(1)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & f(\bm{x}), & f, \bm{h} \in C^2, \\
\text{subject to} & \bm{h}(\bm{x}) = \bm{0}, & \bm{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n, 
\bm{h}(\bm{x}) \in \mathbb{R}^m.
\end{align}
 \qquad(1)
Everything we do can be easily extended to problems having inequality as well as equality constraints for the price of a somewhat more involved notation.




Assume that 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast is a regular point of the constraints.

There is then a Lagrange multiplier vector 𝛌*\bm{\lambda}^\ast such that


∇f(𝐱*)−(𝛌*)⊤∇𝐡(𝐱*)=𝟎,(2)
\nabla f(\bm{x}^\ast) - \left(\bm{\lambda}^\ast\right)^\top \nabla \bm{h}
(\bm{x}^\ast) = \bm{0},
 \qquad(2)
and the Hessian of the Lagrangian ℓ(𝐱,𝛌*)=f(𝐱)−(𝛌*)⊤𝐡(𝐱)\ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}^\ast) = f(\bm{x}) - \left(\bm{\lambda}^\ast\right)^\top \bm{h}(\bm{x})
𝐋(𝐱*)=𝐅(𝐱*)−(𝛌*)⊤𝐇(𝐱*)(3)
\bm{L}(\bm{x}^\ast) = \bm{F}(\bm{x}^\ast) - \left(\bm{\lambda}^\ast\right)^\top \bm{H}(\bm{x}^\ast)
 \qquad(3)
must be positive semidefinite on the tangent subspace
M={𝐱:∇𝐡(𝐱*)=𝟎}. M = \{\bm{x}: \nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}^\ast) = \bm{0}\}. 




Local Convexity Assumption


We assume that the Hessian 𝐋(𝐱*)\bm{L(\bm{x}^\ast)} is positive definite. (We mean that 𝐋(𝐱*)\bm{L(\bm{x}^\ast)} on the whole space ℝn\mathbb{R}^n, not just on the subspace MM.)
This assumption guarantees that the Lagrangian ℓ(𝐱,𝛌*)\ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}^\ast) is locally convex at 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast.




With this assumption, the point 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast is not only a local solution to the constrained problem Equation 1; it is also a local solution to the unconstrained problem

minimizeℓ(𝐱,𝛌*)=f(𝐱)−(𝛌*)⊤𝐡(𝐱)(4)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}^\ast) = f(\bm{x}) - 
\left( \bm{\lambda}^\ast \right)^\top \bm{h}(\bm{x})
\end{align}
 \qquad(4)

For any 𝛌\bm{\lambda} sufficiently close to 𝛌*\bm{\lambda}^\ast, the function ℓ(𝐱,𝛌)\ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}) will have a local minimum point at a point 𝐱\bm{x} near 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast.

This follows by noting that by the implicit function theorem, the eqn. ∇f(𝐱)−𝛌⊤∇𝐡(𝐱)=𝟎
\nabla f(\bm{x}) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \nabla \bm{h}
(\bm{x}) = \bm{0}



has a solution 𝐱\bm{x} near 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast when 𝛌\bm{\lambda} is near 𝛌*\bm{\lambda}^\ast because 𝐋*\bm{L}^\ast is positive definite.

text:
Local Duality





Thus, locally there is a unique correspondence between 𝛌\bm{\lambda} and 𝐱\bm{x} through the solution of the unconstrained problem Equation 4. minimizeℓ(𝐱,𝛌)=f(𝐱)−𝛌⊤𝐡(𝐱).(5)
\begin{align}
\operatorname{minimize} & \ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}) = f(\bm{x}) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \bm{h}(\bm{x}).
\end{align}
 \qquad(5)

This correspondence is continuously differentiable.

Near 𝛌*\bm{\lambda}^\ast we define the dual function ϕ\phi by the equation ϕ(𝛌)≜min𝐱∈𝒩(𝐱*)[ℓ(𝐱,𝛌)=f(𝐱)−𝛌⊤𝐡(𝐱)](6)
\phi(\bm{\lambda}) \triangleq \operatorname{min}_{\bm{x} \in \mathcal{N}(\bm{x}^\ast)} 
\left[ \ell(\bm{x}, \bm{\lambda}) = f(\bm{x}) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \bm{h}(\bm{x}) \right]
 \qquad(6)
We are then able to show that locally the original constrained problem Equation 4 is equivalent to unconstrained local maximization of of the dual function ϕ\phi with respect to 𝛌\bm{\lambda}.

Denote by 𝐱(𝛌)\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}) the unique solution to Equation 5 in the neighborhood of 𝐱*\bm{x}^\ast.








Lemma 1


The dual function ϕ\phi has gradient ∇ϕ(𝛌)=−𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))⊤.(7) \nabla \phi(\bm{\lambda}) = -\bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}))^\top.  \qquad(7)






Proof


We have explicitly from Equation 6 ϕ(𝛌)=f(𝐱(𝛌))−𝛌⊤𝐡(𝐱(𝛌)). \phi(\bm{\lambda}) = f(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})).  Thus ∇ϕ(𝛌)=[∇f(𝐱(𝛌))−𝛌⊤∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))]∇𝐱(𝛌)−𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))⊤. 
\nabla \phi(\bm{\lambda}) = \left[ \nabla f(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) \right] \nabla \bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}) - \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}))^\top. 
 Since the first term on the right vanishes by the defition of 𝐱(𝛌)\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}) (the unique solution to Equation 5), we obtain Equation 7.







Lemma 2


The Hessian of the dual function is 𝚽(𝛌)=−∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))𝐋−1(𝐱(𝛌),𝛌)∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))⊤.(8)
\bm{\Phi}(\bm{\lambda}) = -\nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}))\bm{L}^{-1}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}), \bm{\lambda}) \nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}))^\top.
 \qquad(8)






Proof


By Lemma 1, 𝚽(𝛌)=−∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))∇𝐱(𝛌)\bm{\Phi}(\bm{\lambda}) = -\nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) \nabla \bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}).
Differentiating ∇f(𝐱(𝛌))−𝛌⊤∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))=𝟎\nabla f(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) - \bm{\lambda}^\top \nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda})) = \bm{0} with respect to 𝛌\bm{\lambda}, we obtain
𝐋(𝐱(𝛌),𝛌)∇𝐱(𝛌)−∇𝐡(𝐱(𝛌))⊤=𝟎. 
\bm{L}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}), \bm{\lambda})\nabla \bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}) - \nabla \bm{h}(\bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}))^\top = \bm{0}.

Solving for ∇𝐱(𝛌)\nabla \bm{x}(\bm{\lambda}) and substituting back to the first eqn., we are through.
